transcripts.text: If you don't provide me with a written plan, so be it.  But our team will see you on Thursday or Friday, your call.  Correct.  It sounds like a threat to me.
No, it's a promise.
Yeah, it just does not sound... Oh!  It's not a threat, it's a promise!
Oh gosh!  Oh my goodness!  Oh man, Joe just keeps giving the content!

This guy... There's probably, I haven't seen it yet, but I know I read some best practices that they're looking at, and you're going to see for a little bit at least no touching, like with the gloves or getting that close, you're going to probably see some of that as well.  Okay.  But we'll wait for his plan to see exactly what he comes up with.  And those things are, just to be clear, those are things that we can't regulate.  We are just wanting to work with them closely to ensure the safety of those kids and their families.
Sure.  Okay.  Yes, sir.  Any further discussion?  Yes, sir.  Go ahead.
Mayor, so I just did have another question about the businesses that are reopening.  So I think the chief said that Skateland's going to reopen on Friday, the Skateland, Jim's Bowling Alley.
Jim's opened today.
Jim's opened yesterday.  And the aquarium?
The aquarium will open on Friday.  Friday.
Okay.  I got an email from the owner of the aquarium stating that you requested a written plan for their opening?
Correct.
What was the purpose of that?

The purpose of that is what he wrote that they were not going to keep open or that they were going to close was not in compliance with the order of the governor.  And so what I wanted to sit down with him, just like all the other businesses have done with us, and we get an understanding before they open up of what they can and can't do, And that one business, as you know and you've seen, will push the envelope and we have to catch them doing what's wrong, which is ridiculous.  And so we wanted to make sure that we're all on the same page, that this can be open but this can't.  And it's not an unreasonable thing to ask under the health and safety, and we have a right to do that.  And so... We definitely wanted to make sure that we're all on the same page so that there's no issues once they opened up.  That's what we hope to do.  If we can't get that agreement ahead of time, we'll show up Friday morning and we'll go walk through, the fire chief and the health inspector and everybody else will walk through and look at what they've put in place.  Because everything there is interactive.  And anything that's interactive is supposed to be shut down.  So basically... There's no touch.  And the whole place is an interactive facility.  And so we just want to make sure for the health and safety of our residents and the safety of his employees.  that we're all on the same page of what can and cannot be done.
Okay.  Did you ask other businesses for a written plan?  What other businesses provided a written plan?
We're waiting on the written plans to come in.  But we don't have the problems with other businesses.
What other businesses did you ask for a written plan?

You just heard me talk about the Little League that was doing that.  We had the same conversation with the skating rink.  And the bowling alley has very specific things that they told them in the governor's order.
Wow, they touch those balls.
And there's very specific things in the governor's order about the bowling alleys, but there isn't specific things about the skating rinks and the aquarium.

I'm a little bit concerned by the email that they forwarded to me.  The verbiage in the email line says, if you don't provide me with a written plan, so be it, but our team will see you on Thursday or Friday, your call.  Correct.  It sounds like a threat to me.
No, it's a promise.
Yeah, it just does not sound, you know, we talk about being business friendly and helpful to the community.
Mr.  Bradshaw, I think you're ignoring all the other great things we're doing and you're ignoring the problems.  Can I finish?  Chief, please.
I was speaking.
Let's not interrupt each other.  Let's finish and then Chief, you can go.

And I'm curious as well about how you decided which businesses get signs and which ones don't.  Because as I drive around the city... I see a lot of businesses that have signs, yes, we're open, and there's quite a few that are open that don't have signs.  And if you go and talk to those business owners, excuse me, excuse me, I'm still talking.  If you go and talk to those, you didn't raise your hand, and you're not on camera as requested by the mayor.

Well, wait a minute, Mr.  Bradshaw, hang on just a second, just a second.  Mr.  Zeck, the point of order has been called, and it's... What's the point of order?  The point of order is, yes, tell me what your point of order is specifically.  Is it Ms.  Charles or Ms.  Alcacer?  You have to tell me why.

The point of order is he's gone off topic.  We have a motion and a second on the floor, and he's talking about signs and, like, discriminating on signs and all these other things that aren't part of are of this particular motion.
And that has a valid point.
Mayor, the signs were in the presentation.  I know.
I wish we had.  OK.

The signs were part of the presentation that the chief gave.  So I was talking about the signs.  And I'm talking about how do they determine which businesses have got signs and which ones didn't.  Because as I've gone around town and talked to some businesses, Some of them say they've never been offered signs.

Okay.  It was point of order.  Thank you.  This is not part of the topic.  We're going to move on with the motion and the order.  Motion and the second right now because it is, I wish we had brought that up when we had the sign in other discussion, but I believe we need to limit it to our points right here.  So, yes.
I'm okay with moving on, but I just had a statement or a question.  Every time Chief gets up to talk, why does it always have to be,
